docblock.description: Returns an array of individual Child Tag Objects that belong to the current "parent" tag as defined in the current class ID property.
docblock.long-description:
Some tags may have 'child' tags, this method will access whether a "parent" Tag (as defined in the ID property of the current class instantiation) indeed has children. If so, it will wrap each child in its own Tag Object and wrap them all within a array.

<

p> If the current "parent" tag does not have children, then an empty array is created and returned.

<

p> This will not return "grandchildren", it is a single level query.

docblock.description: Test the privileges of the user account for the connection.
docblock.long-description:
Tests run include:

  • CREATE TABLE
  • INSERT
  • SELECT
  • UPDATE
  • DELETE
  • ALTER TABLE
  • DROP TABLE

These tests must be performed in order, for logical reasons. Execution terminates when the first test fails, and the status flag array is returned then. Returns an array of status flags. Key is the test name. Value is a boolean, true if the test succeeded, and false if it failed.

Alters the structure of an existing database table to conform to the passed data definition.

This function abides by the Exponent Data Definition Language, and interprets its general structure for MySQL.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name of the table to alter

tag.name: param
tag.description: The new data definition for the table. This is expressed in the Exponent Data Definition Language

tag.name: param
tag.description: Information about the table itself.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Whether or not to aggressively update the table definition. An aggressive update will drop columns in the table that are not in the Exponent definition.

docblock.long-description:
Returns true if the query succeeded, and false if an error was returned from the MySQL server.

If you can help it, do not use this function. It presents Database Portability Issues.

Runs a straight SQL query on the database. This is not a very portable way of dealing with the database, and is only provided as a last resort.

tag.description: The SQL query to run

docblock.long-description: Selects an objects from the database. Because of the way Exponent handles objects and database tables, this is akin to SELECTing a single record from a database table. Returns the first record/object found (in the case of multiple-result queries, there is no way to determine which of the set will be returned). If no record(s) match the query, null is returned.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name of the table/object to look at

tag.name: param
tag.description: Criteria used to narrow the result set.

docblock.description: Insert an Object into some table in the Database
docblock.long-description: This method will return the ID assigned to the new record by MySQL. Note that object attributes starting with an underscore ('_') will be ignored and NOT inserted into the table as a field value.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The object to insert.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The logical table name to insert into. This does not include the table prefix, which is automagically prepended for you.

docblock.description: Delete one or more objects from the given table.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name of the table to delete from.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Criteria for determining which record(s) to delete.

docblock.description: Update one or more objects in the database.
docblock.long-description: This function will only update the attributes of the resulting record(s) that are also member attributes of the $object object.

tag.name: param
tag.description: An object specifying the fields and values for updating. In most cases, this will be the altered object originally returned from one of the select* methods.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The table to update in.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Optional criteria used to narrow the result set.

docblock.description: Find the maximum value of a field.
docblock.long-description: This is similar to a standard SELECT MAX(field) ... query.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name of the table to select from.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The attribute name to find a maximum value for.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A comma-separated list of fields (or a single field) name, used for a GROUP BY clause. This can also be passed as an array of fields.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Optional criteria for narrowing the result set.

docblock.description: Find the minimum value of a field.

docblock.description: Increment a numeric table field in a table.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name of the table to increment in.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The field to increment.

tag.name: param

docblock.description: Decrement a numeric table field in a table.

tag.description: The name of the table to decrement in.

tag.description: Optional criteria to determine which records to update.

docblock.description: Check to see if the named table exists in the database.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Name of the table to look for.

docblock.description: Get a list of all tables in the database.
docblock.long-description: Optionally, only the tables in the current logical database (tables with the same prefix) can be retrieved.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Whether to return only the tables for the logical database, or all tables in the physical database.

docblock.description: Runs whatever table optimization routines the database engine supports.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name of the table to optimize.

docblock.description: Retrieve table information for a named table.
docblock.long-description:
Returns an object, with the following attributes:

  • rows -- The number of rows in the table.
  • average_row_length -- The average storage size of a row in the table.
  • data_total -- How much total disk space is used by the table.
  • data_overhead -- How much storage space in the table is unused (for compacting purposes)

docblock.description: Check whether or not a table in the database is empty (0 rows).
docblock.long-description: Returns tue of the specified table has no rows, and false if otherwise.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Name of the table to check.

docblock.description: Returns table information for all tables in the database.
docblock.long-description: This function effectively calls tableInfo() on each table found.

docblock.description: Test the privileges of the user account for the connection.
docblock.long-description:
Tests run include:

  • CREATE TABLE
  • INSERT
  • SELECT
  • UPDATE
  • DELETE
  • ALTER TABLE
  • DROP TABLE

These tests must be performed in order, for logical reasons. Execution terminates when the first test fails, and the status flag array is returned then. Returns an array of status flags. Key is the test name. Value is a boolean, true if the test succeeded, and false if it failed.

docblock.description: Test the privileges of the user account for the connection.
docblock.long-description:
Tests run include:

  • CREATE TABLE
  • INSERT
  • SELECT
  • UPDATE
  • DELETE
  • ALTER TABLE
  • DROP TABLE

These tests must be performed in order, for logical reasons. Execution terminates when the first test fails, and the status flag array is returned then. Returns an array of status flags. Key is the test name. Value is a boolean, true if the test succeeded, and false if it failed.

Alters the structure of an existing database table to conform to the passed data definition.

This function abides by the Exponent Data Definition Language, and interprets its general structure for databases.

tag.description: The new data definition for the table. This is expressed in the Exponent Data Definition Language

tag.description: Information about the table itself.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Whether or not to aggressively update the table definition. An aggressive update will drop columns in the table that are not in the Exponent definition.

docblock.description: This is the class expHistory Exponent History Subsystem
docblock.long-description:
The expHistory class is responsible for keeping track of which pages a user has visited while on the site. It also tracks what type of page/view each one is, viewable, manageable, editable and uses this information to intelligently route the user to proper places. A developer can also use the methods of this class help Exponent know where to route users.

DEFINITIONS

  • viewable - standard (public) page/view like that for showall, show, etc...
  • manageable - page/view with list of editable items for management like manage_tags, etc... Typically you wouldn't edit in this view
  • editable - a page/view used to edit an item or settings

USAGE EXAMPLES:

Example: How to set a history WayPoint

This example shows how you would use expHistory to set a waypoint inside one of your actions

public function showall() {
    expHistory::set('viewable', $this->params);
     $record = new foo($id);
     assign_to_template(array('record'=>$record));
}

Example: Return to a waypoint (automagically)

This example show how to let expHistory::back() automagically determine where to route the user after an action completes

public function delete() {
     $record = new foo($id);
     $record->delete();
     expHistory::back();
}

Example: Return to a waypoint (manually) This example show how use expHistory::returnTo() to manually route the user after an action completes. In this example the user will be routed to the last form he/she was on.

public function delete() {
     $record = new foo($id);
     $record->delete();
     expHistory::returnTo('editable');
}
The constructor will grab the users history from the session. If it is not present in the session it will be initialized and saved later.

docblock.description: This function will redirect the user to the last page or action not marked as editable.
Returns a history item further back in time than the most recent (last) one

// Create PDF object.

docblock.description: messageId() - This will return the unique ID of the mail message.
docblock.long-description:
Courtesy of the underlying Swift mailer:

ID headers contain identifiers for the entity (or the message). The most notable ID header is the Message-ID header on the message itself.

An ID that exists inside an ID header looks more-or-less less like an email address. For example, 1234955437.499becad62ec2@example.org. The part to the left of the @ sign is usually unique, based on the * current time and some random factor. The part on the right is usually a domain name.

tag.name: author
tag.description: Tyler Smart <tyleresmart@gmail.com>

docblock.description: This is the class expPaginator Exponent Pagination Subsystem
docblock.long-description:
The expPaginator class is used to retrieve objects from the database and paginate them and optionally group the by category. It automagically handles the calls to other pages and has built-in sorting using the defined column headers.

Usage Example:


$page = new expPaginator(array(
     'model'=>'faq',
     'where'=>1,
     'limit'=>25,
     'order'=>'rank',
     'controller'=>$this->baseclassname,
     'action'=>$this->params['action'],
     'columns'=>array('In FAQ'=>'include_in_faq', 'Submitted'=>'created_at', 'Submitted By'=>'submitter_name'),
 ));
This is the main entry point for using the expPaginator. See example above.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Use this to set any of the class variables. Ones not passed will be set to a default.

docblock.long-description: An HTML-form building class, that supports registerable and unregisterable controls.

docblock.description: Registers a new Control with the form.
docblock.long-description: This function will simply append the new Control to the end of the Form.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The internal name of the control. This is used for referring to the control later. If this is a null string, the Control will not be registered, and this function will return false.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The Control object to register with the form.

tag.name: param
tag.description: boolean dictating what to do if a Control with the specified internal name already exists on the form. If passed as true (default), the existing Control will be replaced. Otherwise, the Control registration will fail and return false.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Returns true if the new Control was registered.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The internal name of the control to remove from the Form.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Returns true if the Control was unregistered.

docblock.description: Registers a new Control, placing it after a pre-existing named Control.
docblock.long-description: If the Control that the caller wants to insert after does not exist, the new Control is appended to the end of the Form.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The internal name of the Control to register the new Control after.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The internal name of the new Control.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The Control object to register with the Form.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Returns true if the new Control was registered.

docblock.description: Registers a new Control, placing it before a pre-existing named Control.
docblock.long-description: If the Control that the caller wants to insert the new Control before does not exist, the new Control is prepended to the form.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The internal name of the Control to register the new Control before.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The internal name of the new Control.

tag.name: param
tag.description: the Control object to register with the Form.

tag.name: return
tag.description: Returns true if the new Control was registered.

docblock.description: Convert the form to HTML output.

tag.name: return
tag.description: The HTML code use to display the form to the browser.

docblock.description: exdoc Create an image resource handle (from GD) for a given filename.
docblock.long-description:
This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry. It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

At this point, the user should have called self::getImageInfo on the filename and verified that the file does indeed exist, and is readable. A safeguard check is in place, however.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path/filename of the image.

docblock.description: exdoc Create a new blank image resource, with the specified width and height.
docblock.long-description: This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry. It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

tag.name: param
tag.description: Width of the image resource to create (in pixels)

tag.name: param
tag.description: Height of the image resource to create (in pixels)

docblock.description: exdoc Proportionally scale an image by a specific percentage This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry.
docblock.long-description: It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path/filename of the image to scale.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The scaling factor, as a decimal (i.e. 0.5 for 50%)

docblock.description: exdoc Proportionally scale an image to a given width.
docblock.long-description: Height adjusts accordingly. This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry. It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path/filename of the image to scale.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The desired width of the scaled image, in pixels.

docblock.description: exdoc Proportionally scale an image to a given height.
docblock.long-description: Width adjusts accordingly. This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry. It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path/filename of the image to scale.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The desired height of the scaled image, in pixels.

docblock.description: exdoc Proportionally scale an image to fit within the given width / height.
docblock.long-description: This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry. It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path/filename of the image to scale.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The maximum width of the scaled image, in pixels.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The maximum height of the scaled image, in pixels.

docblock.description: exdoc Scale an image to a square keeping the image aspect ratio.
docblock.long-description: If the image is smaller in either dimension than request square side original is returned. Image is first cropped to a square of length smaller of width or height and then resized. This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry. It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path/filename of the image to scale.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param int $size The desired side length of the scaled image, in pixels.

docblock.description: exdoc Scale an image to a given width and height, without regard to aspect ratio.
docblock.long-description: This is a wrapper around various GD functions, to provide Exponent programmers a single point of entry. It also handles situations where there is no GD support compiled into the server. (In this case, null is returned).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path/filename of the image to scale.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The desired width of the scaled image, in pixels.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The desired height of the scaled image, in pixels.

docblock.description: exdoc Lists files and directories under a given parent directory.
docblock.long-description: Returns an associative, flat array of files and directories. The key is the full file or directory name, and the value is the file or directory name.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The path of the directory to look at.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A boolean dictating whether to descend into subdirectories recursively, and list files and subdirectories.

tag.name: param
tag.description: An optional file extension. If specified, only files ending with that file extension will show up in the list. Directories are not affected.

tag.name: param
tag.description: An array of directory names to exclude. These names are path-independent. Specifying "dir" will ignore all directories and sub-directories named "dir", regardless of their parent.

docblock.description: exdoc Looks at the filesystem structure surrounding the destination and determines if the web server can create a new file there.
docblock.long-description:
Returns one of the following:
SYS_FILES_NOTWRITABLE - unable to create files in destination
SYS_FILES_SUCCESS - A file or directory can be created in destination
SYS_FILES_FOUNDFILE - Found destination to be a file, not a directory

tag.name: param
tag.description: Path to the directory to check

docblock.description: exdoc Copies just the directory structure (including subdirectories) of a given directory.
docblock.long-description: Any files in the source directory are ignore, and duplicate copies are made (no symlinks).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The directory to copy structure from. This must be a full path.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The directory to create duplicate structure in. If this directory is not empty, you may run into some problems, because of file/directory conflicts.

tag.name: param
tag.description: An array of directory names to exclude. These names are path-independent. Specifying "dir" will ignore all directories and sub-directories named "dir", regardless of their parent.

docblock.description: exdoc This function takes a database object and dumps all of the records in all of the tables into a string.
docblock.long-description: The contents of the string are suitable for storage in a file or other permanent mechanism, and is in the EQL format naively handled by the current implementation.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The database object to dump to EQL.

docblock.description: exdoc This function restores a database (overwriting all data in any existing tables) from an EQL object dump.
docblock.long-description: Returns true if the restore was a success and false if something went horribly wrong (unable to read file, etc.) Even if true is returned, there is a chance that some errors were encountered. Check $errors to be sure everything was fine.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The database to restore to

tag.name: param
tag.description: The filename of the EQL file to restore from

tag.name: param
tag.description: A referenced array that stores errors. Whatever variable is passed in this argument will contain all errors encountered during the parse/restore.

docblock.description: This converts the sql statement into a nice CSV.
docblock.long-description:
We grab the items array which is stored funkily in the DB in an associative array when we pull it. So basically our aray looks like this:

ITEMS {[id]=>myID, [Name]=>name, [Address]=>myaddr} {[id]=>myID1, [Name]=>name1, [Address]=>myaddr1} {[id]=>myID2, [Name]=>name2, [Address]=>myaddr2} {[id]=>myID3, [Name]=>name3, [Address]=>myaddr3} {[id]=>myID4, [Name]=>name4, [Address]=>myaddr4} {[id]=>myID5, [Name]=>name5, [Address]=>myaddr5}

So by nature of the array, the keys are repetated in each line (id, name, etc) So if we want to make a header row, we just run through once at the beginning and use the array_keys function to strip out a functional header

markers.fixme: we shouldn't need to return here, right?

docblock.long-description:
This source file can be used to communicate with Twitter (http://twitter.com)

The class is documented in the file itself. If you find any bugs help me out and report them. Reporting can be done by sending an email to php-twitter-bugs[at]verkoyen[dot]eu. If you report a bug, make sure you give me enough information (include your code).

Changelog since 2.1.1 - code styling - no more converting to integer for the cursor (thx to Jamaica)

Changelog since 2.1.0 - fixed issue with generation of basestring - added a new method: http://dev.twitter.com/doc/post/:user/:list_id/create_all

Changelog since 2.0.3 - made a lot of changes to reflect the current API, some of the methods aren't backwards compatible, so be carefull before upgrading

Changelog since 2.0.2 - tested geo* - implemented accountUpdateProfileImage - implemented accountUpdateProfileBackgroundImage - fixed issue with GET and POST (thx to Luiz Felipe) - added a way to detect open_basedir (thx to Lee Kindness)

Changelog since 2.0.1 - Fixed some documentation - Added a new method: usersProfileImage - Fixed trendsLocation - Added new GEO-methods: geoSearch, geoSimilarPlaces, geoPlaceCreate (not tested because geo-services were disabled.) - Added legalToS - Added legalPrivacy - Fixed helpTest

Changelog since 2.0.0 - no more fatal if twitter is over capacity - fix for calculating the header-string (thx to Dextro) - fix for userListsIdStatuses (thx to Josh)

tag.name: param
tag.description: The parameters.

docblock.description: All OAuth 1.0 requests use the same basic algorithm for creating a signature base string and a signature.
docblock.long-description: The signature base string is composed of the HTTP method being used, followed by an ampersand ("&") and then the URL-encoded base URL being accessed, complete with path (but not query parameters), followed by an ampersand ("&"). Then, you take all query parameters and POST body parameters (when the POST body is of the URL-encoded type, otherwise the POST body is ignored), including the OAuth parameters necessary for negotiation with the request at hand, and sort them in lexicographical order by first parameter name and then parameter value (for duplicate parameters), all the while ensuring that both the key and the value for each parameter are URL encoded in isolation. Instead of using the equals ("=") sign to mark the key/value relationship, you use the URL-encoded form of "%3D". Each parameter is then joined by the URL-escaped ampersand sign, "%26".

docblock.description: Returns the 20 most recent statuses from non-protected users who have set a custom user icon.
docblock.long-description: The public timeline is cached for 60 seconds and requesting it more often than that is unproductive and a waste of resources.

docblock.description: Returns the 20 most recent statuses, including retweets if they exist, posted by the authenticating user and the user's they follow.
docblock.long-description: This is the same timeline seen by a user when they login to twitter.com. This method is identical to statusesFriendsTimeline, except that this method always includes retweets.

docblock.description: Returns the 20 most recent statuses posted by the authenticating user and the user's they follow.
docblock.long-description: This is the same timeline seen by a user when they login to twitter.com. This method is identical to statuses/home_timeline, except that this method will only include retweets if the includeRts parameter is set.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID.

tag.name: param
tag.description: When set to true the timeline will contain native retweets (if they exist) in addition to the standard stream of tweets. The output format of retweeted tweets is identical to the representation you see in home_timeline. Note: If you're using the trim_user parameter in conjunction with include_rts, the retweets will still contain a full user object.

tag.name: param
tag.description: When set to true each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags.

docblock.description: Returns the 20 most recent statuses posted by the authenticating user.
docblock.long-description: It is also possible to request another user's timeline by using the screen_name or user_id parameter. The other users timeline will only be visible if they are not protected, or if the authenticating user's follow request was accepted by the protected user. The timeline returned is the equivalent of the one seen when you view a user's profile on twitter.com.

docblock.description: Returns the 20 most recent mentions (status containing @username) for the authenticating user.
docblock.long-description: The timeline returned is the equivalent of the one seen when you view your mentions on twitter.com.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $string [optional] $sinceId Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $string [optional] $maxId Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $int [optional] $count Specifies the number of records to retrieve. May not be greater than 200.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $int [optional] $page Specifies the page of results to retrieve.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $bool [optional] $trimUser When set to either true, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $bool [optional] $includeRts When set to either true, the timeline will contain native retweets (if they exist) in addition to the standard stream of tweets. The output format of retweeted tweets is identical to the representation you see in home_timeline. Note: If you're using the trim_user parameter in conjunction with include_rts, the retweets will still contain a full user object.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $bool [optional] $includeEntities When set to either true, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future.

docblock.description: Access to Twitter's suggested user list.
docblock.long-description: This returns the list of suggested user categories. The category can be used in the users/suggestions/category endpoint to get the users in that category.

docblock.description: Access the users in a given category of the Twitter suggested user list.
docblock.long-description: It is recommended that end clients cache this data for no more than one hour.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The short name of list or a category.

docblock.description: Access the profile image in various sizes for the user with the indicated screen_name.
docblock.long-description: If no size is provided the normal image is returned. This method return an URL to the actual image resource. This method should only be used by application developers to lookup or check the profile image URL for a user. This method must not be used as the image source URL presented to users of your application.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The screen name of the user for whom to return results for. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

tag.name: internal
tag.description: param $string [optional] $size Specifies the size of image to fetch. Not specifying a size will give the default, normal size of 48px by 48px. Valid options include: bigger (73x73px), normal (48x48px), mini (24x24px).

docblock.description: Returns a user's friends, each with current status inline.
docblock.long-description:
They are ordered by the order in which the user followed them, most recently followed first, 100 at a time. (Please note that the result set isn't guaranteed to be 100 every time as suspended users will be filtered out.)

Use the cursor option to access older friends. With no user specified, request defaults to the authenticated user's friends. It's also possible to request another user's friends list via the id, screen_name or user_id parameter.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Specfies the ID of the user for whom to return results for. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Specfies the screen name of the user for whom to return results for. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Breaks the results into pages. This is recommended for users who are following many users. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned to in the response body's next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list.

tag.name: param
tag.description: When set to true each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags.

docblock.description: Returns the authenticating user's followers, each with current status inline.

docblock.description: Returns tweets that match a specified query.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Search query. Should be URL encoded. Queries will be limited by complexity.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Restricts tweets to the given language, given by an ISO 639-1 code.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Specify the language of the query you are sending (only ja is currently effective). This is intended for language-specific clients and the default should work in the majority of cases.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The number of tweets to return per page, up to a max of 100.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The page number (starting at 1) to return, up to a max of roughly 1500 results (based on rpp * page).

tag.name: param
tag.description: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occurred since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Returns tweets generated before the given date. Date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Returns tweets by users located within a given radius of the given latitude/longitude. The location is preferentially taking from the Geotagging API, but will fall back to their Twitter profile. The parameter value is specified by "latitude,longitude,radius", where radius units must be specified as either "mi" (miles) or "km" (kilometers). Note that you cannot use the near operator via the API to geocode arbitrary locations; however you can use this geocode parameter to search near geocodes directly.

tag.name: param
tag.description: When true, prepends ":" to the beginning of the tweet. This is useful for readers that do not display Atom's author field. The default is false.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Specifies what type of search results you would prefer to receive. The current default is "mixed." Valid values include: mixed, recent, popular.

Retrieve the data for a saved search owned by the authenticating user specified by the given id.

tag.description: The ID of the desired saved search.

docblock.long-description: The search specified by id must be owned by the authenticating user.

tag.name: param

tag.name: param
tag.description: The token.

docblock.description: Allows a Consumer application to use an OAuth request_token to request user authorization.
docblock.long-description: This method is a replacement fulfills Secion 6.2 of the OAuth 1.0 authentication flow for applications using the Sign in with Twitter authentication flow. The method will use the currently logged in user as the account to for access authorization unless the force_login parameter is set to true REMARK: This method seems not to work @later

tag.name: param
tag.description: [optional] $force Force the authentication.

docblock.description: Returns the locations that Twitter has trending topic information for.
docblock.long-description: The response is an array of "locations" that encode the location's WOEID (a Yahoo! Where On Earth ID) and some other human-readable information such as a canonical name and country the location belongs in. The WOEID that is returned in the location object is to be used when querying for a specific trend.

tag.name: param
tag.description: If passed in conjunction with long, then the available trend locations will be sorted by distance to the lat and long passed in. The sort is nearest to furthest.

tag.name: param
tag.description: If passed in conjunction with lat, then the available trend locations will be sorted by distance to the lat and long passed in. The sort is nearest to furthest.

docblock.description: Returns the top 10 trending topics for a specific location Twitter has trending topic information for.
docblock.long-description: The response is an array of "trend" objects that encode the name of the trending topic, the query parameter that can be used to search for the topic on Search, and the direct URL that can be issued against Search. This information is cached for five minutes, and therefore users are discouraged from querying these endpoints faster than once every five minutes. Global trends information is also available from this API by using a WOEID of 1.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The WOEID of the location to be querying for.

docblock.description: Search for places that can be attached to a statuses/update.
docblock.long-description: Given a latitude and a longitude pair, an IP address, or a name, this request will return a list of all the valid places that can be used as the place_id when updating a status. Conceptually, a query can be made from the user's location, retrieve a list of places, have the user validate the location he or she is at, and then send the ID of this location with a call to statuses/update. This is the recommended method to use find places that can be attached to statuses/update. Unlike geo/reverse_geocode which provides raw data access, this endpoint can potentially re-order places with regards to the user who is authenticated. This approach is also preferred for interactive place matching with the user.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The latitude to search around. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn't a corresponding long parameter.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The longitude to search around. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.

tag.name: param
tag.description: Free-form text to match against while executing a geo-based query, best suited for finding nearby locations by name.

tag.name: param
tag.description: An IP address. Used when attempting to fix geolocation based off of the user's IP address.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A hint on the "region" in which to search. If a number, then this is a radius in meters, but it can also take a string that is suffixed with ft to specify feet. If this is not passed in, then it is assumed to be 0m. If coming from a device, in practice, this value is whatever accuracy the device has measuring its location (whether it be coming from a GPS, WiFi triangulation, etc.).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The minimal granularity of data to return. If this is not passed in, then neighborhood is assumed. city can also be passed.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A hint as to the number of results to return. This does not guarantee that the number of results returned will equal max_results, but instead informs how many "nearby" results to return. Ideally, only pass in the number of places you intend to display to the user here.

tag.name: param
tag.description: This is the place_id which you would like to restrict the search results to. Setting this value means only places within the given place_id will be found.

tag.name: param
tag.description: This parameter searches for places which have this given. This should be an key-value-pair-array.

docblock.description: Locates places near the given coordinates which are similar in name.
docblock.long-description: Conceptually you would use this method to get a list of known places to choose from first. Then, if the desired place doesn't exist, make a request to post/geo/place to create a new one. The token contained in the response is the token needed to be able to create a new place.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The location's latitude that this tweet refers to.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The location's longitude that this tweet refers to.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name a place is known as.

tag.name: param
tag.description: This is the place_id which you would like to restrict the search results to. Setting this value means only places within the given place_id will be found.

tag.name: param
tag.description: This parameter searches for places which have this given. This should be an key-value-pair-array.

docblock.description: Search for places (cities and neighborhoods) that can be attached to a statuses/update.
docblock.long-description: Given a latitude and a longitude, return a list of all the valid places that can be used as a place_id when updating a status. Conceptually, a query can be made from the user's location, retrieve a list of places, have the user validate the location he or she is at, and then send the ID of this location up with a call to statuses/update. There are multiple granularities of places that can be returned -- "neighborhoods", "cities", etc. At this time, only United States data is available through this method. This API call is meant to be an informative call and will deliver generalized results about geography.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The location's latitude that this tweet refers to.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The location's longitude that this tweet refers to.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A hint on the "region" in which to search. If a number, then this is a radius in meters, but it can also take a string that is suffixed with ft to specify feet. If this is not passed in, then it is assumed to be 0m. If coming from a device, in practice, this value is whatever accuracy the device has measuring its location (whether it be coming from a GPS, WiFi triangulation, etc.).

tag.name: param
tag.description: The minimal granularity of data to return. If this is not passed in, then neighborhood is assumed. city can also be passed.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A hint as to the number of results to return. This does not guarantee that the number of results returned will equal max_results, but instead informs how many "nearby" results to return. Ideally, only pass in the number of places you intend to display to the user here.

docblock.description: Find out more details of a place that was returned from the geo/reverse_geocode method.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The id of the place.

tag.name: param
tag.description: A place in the world. These IDs can be retrieved from geo/reverse_geocode.

docblock.description: Creates a new place at the given latitude and longitude.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The name a place is known as.

tag.name: param
tag.description: This is the place_id which you would like to restrict the search results to. Setting this value means only places within the given place_id will be found.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The token found in the response from geo/similar_places.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The latitude the place is located at. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn't a corresponding long parameter.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The longitude the place is located at. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, if it is not a number, if geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter.

tag.name: param
tag.description: This parameter searches for places which have this given. This should be an key-value-pair-array.

docblock.description: exdoc This function pulls a group object form the subsystems storage mechanism, according to its ID.
docblock.long-description:
For the default implementation, this is equivalent to a $db->selectObject() call, but it may not be the same for other implementations. Returns a group object, and null if no group was found.

This function does NOT perform group caching like the user::getUserById function does. Multiple calls to retrieve the same group result in multiple calls to the database.

docblock.description: exdoc This method queries the ork/modules/users/extensions/ directory for a list of installed User Profile Extension class files.
docblock.long-description:
It returns the class names, in an array. This function does not take into account whether or not the administrator has activated or deactivated certain profiles.

In order to be picked up by this function (and therefore the rest of the Users subsystem) a profile extension filename MUST end in 'extension.php', and therefore the classname MUST end in 'extension'.

Returns an array of installed (but not necessarily activated) user profile extensions. If this array is empty, either Exponent encountered a problem reading the Profile Extensions directory, or there were simply no extensions to list.

exdoc This function pulls a user object from the subsystems storage mechanism according to its ID.
docblock.long-description:
For the default implementation, this is equivalent to a $db->selectObject() call, but it may not be the same for other implementations. Returns a basic user object, and null if no user was found.

This function uses the exclusive global variable $SYS_USERS_CACHE to cache previously retrieved user accounts, so that subsequent requests for the same user object do not result in another trip to the database engine.

tag.name: param
tag.description: The id of the user account to retrieve.

docblock.description: This converts the sql statement into a nice CSV.
docblock.long-description:
We grab the items array which is stored funkily in the DB in an associative array when we pull it. So basically our aray looks like this:

ITEMS {[id]=>myID, [Name]=>name, [Address]=>myaddr} {[id]=>myID1, [Name]=>name1, [Address]=>myaddr1} {[id]=>myID2, [Name]=>name2, [Address]=>myaddr2} {[id]=>myID3, [Name]=>name3, [Address]=>myaddr3} {[id]=>myID4, [Name]=>name4, [Address]=>myaddr4} {[id]=>myID5, [Name]=>name5, [Address]=>myaddr5}

So by nature of the array, the keys are repetated in each line (id, name, etc) So if we want to make a header row, we just run through once at the beginning and use the array_keys function to strip out a functional header

docblock.long-description:
This smarty plugin provides php switch statement functionality in smarty tags. To install this plugin drop it into your smarty plugins folder. You will also need to manually load the plugin sot hat all the hooks are registered properly. Add the following line after you load smarty and create an instance of it in your source code.

  $this->smartyObj->loadPlugin('smarty_compiler_switch');

tag.name: author
tag.description: Jeremy Pyne <jeremy.pyne@gmail.com> - Donations: Accepted via PayPal at the above address. - Updated: 02/10/2010 - Version 3.2 - File: smarty/plugins/compiler.switch.php - Licence: CC:BY/NC/SA http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/ - Updates Version 2: Changed the break attribute to cause a break to be printed before the next case, instead of before this case. This way makes more sense and simplifies the code. This change in incompatible with code in from version one. This is written to support nested switches and will work as expected. Version 2.1: Added {/case} tag, this is identical to {break}. Version 3: Updated switch statment to support Smarty 3. This update is NOT backwards compatible but the old version is still maintained. Version 3.1: Added a prefilter to re-enable the shorthand {switch $myvar} support. To use the shorthand form you will need to add the following line to your code. $smarty->loadPlugin('smarty_compiler_switch'); Version 3.2: Fixed a bug when chaining multiple {case} statements without a {break}. Version 3.5: Updated to work with Smarty 3.0 release. (Tested and working with 3.0.5, no longer compatible with 3.0rcx releases.) Version 3.6: Updated to work with Smarty 3.1 release. (Tested and working on 3.1.3, No longer compatible with 3.0 releases.) - Bugs/Notes:

tag.name: subpackage

function.name: smarty_postfilter_switch

docblock.description: Filter the template after it is generated to fix switch bugs.
docblock.long-description: Remove any spaces after the 'switch () {' code and before the first case. Any tabs or spaces for layout would cause php errors witch this reged will fix.
A variable must be passed to switch on. Also, the switch can only directly contain {case} and {default} tags.

docblock.description: Print out a case line for this switch.
docblock.long-description: A condition must be passed to match on. This can only go in {switch} tags. If break is passed, a {break} will be rendered before the next case.

docblock.description: Print out a default line for this switch.
docblock.long-description: This can only go in {switch} tags. If break is passed, a {break} will be rendered before the next case.

docblock.description: Print out a break command for the switch.
docblock.long-description: This can only go inside of {case} tags.

docblock.description: Print out a break command for the switch.
docblock.long-description: This can only go inside of {case} tags.
